unnormalised: Someone asked me about the difference between PAN, TAN, and GSTIN for businesses in India, so here's a breakdown. It's important to understand each of these for compliance.
normalised: Someone asked me about the difference between P-A-N, T-A-N, and G-S-T-I-N for businesses in India, so here's a breakdown. It's important to understand each of these for compliance.

unnormalised: PAN, or Permanent Account Number, is a 10-character alphanumeric identifier issued by the Income Tax Department. It's essential for all financial transactions exceeding Rs. 50,000 and is linked to your income tax filings. Think of it as your individual or business's main financial identifier. You absolutely need it for filing ITR, opening a bank account, etc. Make sure the details match your official records; even a small error can cause issues later.
normalised: P-A-N, or Permanent Account Number, is a ten character alphanumeric identifier issued by the Income Tax Department. It's essential for all financial transactions exceeding rupee fifty thousand and is linked to your income tax filings. Think of it as your individual or business's main financial identifier. You absolutely need it for filing I-T-R, opening a bank account, etcetera. Make sure the details match your official records; even a small error can cause issues later.

unnormalised: TAN, or Tax Deduction and Collection Account Number, is also a 10-character alphanumeric code but is required for businesses that deduct or collect tax at source (TDS/TCS). If your company is deducting TDS u/s 194J or any other section, you need a TAN. It’s crucial for filing TDS returns, and you can't file them without a valid TAN registered against your PAN. Finally, GSTIN, a 15-digit Goods and Services Tax Identification Number, is necessary for businesses registered under the GST regime. If your turnover is more than the threshold limit of Rs. 20 lakh (Rs. 10 lakh for special category states) or if you're involved in inter-state supply, registration is mandatory.
normalised: T-A-N, or Tax Deduction and Collection Account Number, is also a ten character alphanumeric code but is required for businesses that deduct or collect tax at source (T-D-S slash T-C-S). If your company is deducting T-D-S under section one hundred and ninety four J or any other section, you need a T-A-N. It’s crucial for filing T-D-S returns, and you can't file them without a valid T-A-N registered against your P-A-N. Finally, G-S-T-I-N, a fifteen digit Goods and Services Tax Identification Number, is necessary for businesses registered under the G-S-T regime. If your turnover is more than the threshold limit of rupee twenty lakh (rupee ten lakh for special category states) or if you're involved in inter-state supply, registration is mandatory.
